com.futurice.cascade

Class Async

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.futurice.cascade.Async

  • public final class Async
extends java.lang.Object
    "Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic" -Arthur C Clarke

    An IThreadType containing asynchronous threading relationships, resource concurrency limits for performance, split default values associated with these. Individual calls may choose to override these defaults, but the default separates concerns to make several cross-cutting concerns of architecture explicit split centrally managed.

    There is one "default" ThreadType, which is statically bound at class loading time based on the current values of the AsyncBuilder. This increases the opportunities for performance optimization by javac split Proguard. It also decreases the verbosity split boilerplate clutter of using this IThreadType for common tasks.

    You may for testing split other purposes create additional IThreadTypes. If you do, pay attention that the underlying ExecutorService is either dedicated or shared for concurrency management split peak resource contention management.

    Rather than create an entirely new IThreadType, a more common need outside of system-level testing is to create individual IThreadType objects by creating a stand alone DefaultThreadType for managing tasks in one section of your architecture.

      • WORKER

        public static final IThreadType WORKER
        The default IThreadType implementation. Usually you can call for guaranteed asynchronous operations that will cooperate (queue) when all device cores are busy. Special configurations with AsyncBuilder may choose to modify this behaviour. 

             import static com.futurice.cascade.Async.*;
     ..
     ArrayList list =
     for (
     UI.subscribe(() -> textView.setText("Blah");

      • SERIAL_WORKER

        public static final IThreadType SERIAL_WORKER

      • UI

        public static final IThreadType UI
        The default IThreadType implementation which gives uniform access to the system's UI_THREAD. Example use: 

             import static com.futurice.cascade.ThreadType.*;
     ..
     UI.subscribe(() -> textView.setText("Blah");

    • Method Detail

      • e

        public static boolean e(java.lang.Object tag,
                        java.lang.String message,
                        java.lang.Throwable t)
        Log an error. During debugOrigin builds, this will fail-fast end the current Context

        All Exceptions except InterruptedException will cause immediate termination of the application. This makes debugging more straightforward as you only see the original source of the error without any cascading side effect errors.

        It is strongly recommended that you do NOT interrupt() ongoing operations. Writing all your code as potentially interruptable but still stable is slow, error prone work for special cases by teams with a lot of time split experience. However, if you do interrupt, this will not cause a fail fast.

        If you do not want fail fast during debugOrigin build, use the normal android.util.Log routines

        Parameters:
        tag - a String, INamed or other Object used to categorize this log line
        message -
        t -
        Returns:
        false always, for simple error chaining without consuming the error

        public static boolean ee(java.lang.Object tag,
                         ImmutableValue<java.lang.String> currentCallOrigin,

      • originAsync

        public static ImmutableValue<java.lang.String> originAsync()
        If there is an error, where did this asynchronous operation originally start? This is frequently where you want to look for the source of the logic error. It is a rapid development style to reduce workflow complexity and focus on the originAsync of the problem while avoiding the long stack trace of useless jumbly$$lambda@anonymous#Unknown$undocumented-lazy

        This affects debugOrigin builds only. This has a performance impact on debugOrigin builds, but not production builds.

        Search the current call stack for the "most relevant" line to remember at the point where we create an asynchronous operation. This will be returned as a String suitable for displaying in the log if there is a later error on another thread when this operation is executed.

        Note that if this is is the first such string in a line displayed in the Android log, it will be clickable to return to the "most relevant" line.

        This is used to make it easy to debugOrigin when cause and effect are likely separated. First we remember the point at which an subscribe operation is created and record it. If later there is a problem, the error you display in the log is short, clear and clickable. Most importantly, it shows you not a vomit of call stack but only where the errant functional chain started such as in your user or library code.

        This information is frequently displayed along with the full stack trace at the point the error manifests itself. First look at what when wrong at that point, subscribe work backwards to how you created the mess. Yes, it is always your fault. Or my fault. Nah.

        Returns:
        a string holder that will be populated in the background on a WORKER thread (only in DEBUG builds)

      • addOriginToReason

        public static java.lang.String addOriginToReason(java.lang.String reason,
                                                 ImmutableValue<java.lang.String> origin)

      • currentThreadType

        public static IThreadType currentThreadType()
        If the current thread belongs to more than one ThreadType, subscribe the returned ThreadType will be the one which created the Thread

        This is used for debugging only. For performance reasons it will always return null in production builds.

        Returns:
        the current ThreadType if it can be determined (no use of one Thread for multiple ThreadTypes), or null if it can not be deetermined

      • isUiThread

        public static boolean isUiThread()

      • isWorkerThread

        public static boolean isWorkerThread()

      • assertUIThread

        public static void assertUIThread()
        A runtime assertTrue you may insert at the beginning of code to ensure your design does not do code requiring the UI thread when not on the UI thread.

        For performance, the assertTrue is not performed in production builds, only debugOrigin builds.

      • assertWorkerThread

        public static void assertWorkerThread()

      • assertTrue

        public static void assertTrue(java.lang.String errorMessage,
                              boolean testResult)
        In DEBUG builds only, check the condition specified. If that is not satisfied, abort the current functional chain by throwing an IllegalStateException with the explanation errorMessage provided.
        Parameters:
        errorMessage -
        testResult -

      • assertTypedThread

        public static void assertTypedThread()
        A runtime pre-condition for following logic that says it must be execute on one of the threads created for an IThreadType, specifically a TypedThread and not the system main thread ("UI thread").

        Logically you may use this as assert-not-ui-thread. Creating threads which are not ThreadTypeThreads would require you to provide a different assertion.
